items.text: I am great at what I do, and I love when others recognize that.
items.rationale: Reflects grandiose self-evaluation combined with striving for social admiration, core components of the admiration pathway.

items.text: I often imagine how far my talents could take me in life.
items.rationale: Captures grandiose fantasies about one's own potential, a key facet of narcissistic admiration.

items.text: People are naturally drawn to my charisma and energy.
items.rationale: Reflects charmingness and the belief in one's social magnetism, central to the striving for uniqueness facet.

items.text: I know how to captivate a room when I walk in.
items.rationale: Describes charming self-presentation and confidence in one's social impact, a hallmark of admiration-seeking behavior.

items.text: I deserve special treatment because of the unique qualities I bring to the table.
items.rationale: Reflects striving for uniqueness and a grandiose sense of entitlement rooted in perceived exceptional qualities.

items.text: I frequently daydream about achieving something extraordinary that will make me famous.
items.rationale: Grandiose fantasy is a core facet of narcissistic admiration, involving visions of outstanding success and recognition.

items.text: I have a natural gift for making people like me.
items.rationale: Captures the charmingness facet—belief in one's interpersonal appeal and ability to win others over.

items.text: One day, people will look back and realize just how exceptional I truly am.
items.rationale: Reflects grandiose fantasy about future recognition, a defining feature of the admiration dimension.

items.text: I enjoy being the center of attention because I usually have the most interesting things to say.
items.rationale: Combines striving for uniqueness with charming self-presentation and grandiose self-evaluation.

items.text: I can easily win people over with my personality and wit.
items.rationale: Directly taps the charmingness facet of narcissistic admiration—confidence in one's social skillfulness.

items.text: I believe I am destined for greatness in ways most people aren't.
items.rationale: Captures both grandiose fantasy and striving for uniqueness, core admiration facets.

items.text: When I share my accomplishments, I can tell people are genuinely impressed.
items.rationale: Reflects grandiose self-evaluation and the interpersonal strategy of eliciting admiration from others.

items.text: I sometimes feel I have qualities that set me apart, though I try not to show it too much.
items.rationale: Suggests striving for uniqueness but the modesty qualifier introduces ambiguity; could reflect healthy self-esteem.

items.text: I put a lot of effort into presenting myself in the best possible light at social events.
items.rationale: Could reflect charming self-presentation or general impression management not specific to narcissism.

items.text: When someone outshines me, I feel a strong urge to prove I'm actually better.
items.rationale: The competitive drive to reassert superiority could reflect admiration-seeking (proving uniqueness) but the reactive, antagonistic quality also maps onto narcissistic rivalry's devaluation of others.

items.text: Most people I meet are not nearly as competent as they think they are.
items.rationale: Directly captures the devaluation of others facet—dismissing others' abilities to maintain self-superiority.

items.text: I get irritated when someone who is clearly less talented than me receives praise.
items.rationale: Reflects aggressiveness triggered by perceived threats to one's superiority, a core rivalry dynamic.

items.text: If someone criticizes me publicly, I will find a way to make them regret it.
items.rationale: Captures the aggressiveness facet of rivalry—retaliatory behavior in response to ego threats.

items.text: I secretly enjoy it when people I compete with fail.
items.rationale: Reflects the antagonistic, zero-sum interpersonal orientation and schadenfreude characteristic of narcissistic rivalry.

items.text: People who get ahead in life usually do so through luck or connections, not real ability.
items.rationale: Devaluation of others' achievements to protect one's own sense of superiority is a hallmark of rivalry.

items.text: I tend to be suspicious of people who are overly friendly—they usually want something.
items.rationale: Reflects the interpersonal distrust and defensive self-protection characteristic of the rivalry pathway.

items.text: When someone succeeds where I haven't, I can't help but look for flaws in what they did.
items.rationale: Captures devaluation of others as a defensive strategy against ego threat from others' success.

items.text: I would rather tear down someone's argument completely than find common ground.
items.rationale: Reflects the aggressive, combative interpersonal style and need to dominate that defines rivalry.

items.text: Other people's success often feels like a personal threat to me.
items.rationale: Directly captures the ego-threat sensitivity and zero-sum thinking central to narcissistic rivalry.

items.text: I find it hard to be genuinely happy for a colleague who gets a promotion I wanted.
items.rationale: Reflects the inability to celebrate others' achievements due to perceived threat to self-worth, a rivalry hallmark.

items.text: I sometimes point out other people's weaknesses to make sure everyone sees the full picture.
items.rationale: Rationalized devaluation of others—undermining competitors under the guise of objectivity is characteristic of rivalry.

items.text: I don't forgive easily when someone has disrespected me.
items.rationale: Captures the grudge-holding and retaliatory tendencies stemming from ego-threat sensitivity in the rivalry dimension.

items.text: I sometimes feel like I need to keep my guard up around people who might outperform me.
items.rationale: Suggests defensive self-protection against ego threats but the self-awareness and hedging reduce diagnostic clarity.

items.text: I can be a bit competitive, and I don't always handle losing gracefully.
items.rationale: Acknowledges competitive aggressiveness but the understated, self-aware tone could reflect normal competitiveness rather than pathological rivalry.

items.text: I know I'm better than most people, and I don't see why I should pretend otherwise.
items.rationale: The grandiose self-evaluation maps onto admiration, but the dismissive, antagonistic tone toward others and refusal to modulate self-presentation suggests rivalry's devaluation and aggressiveness.
